entry.title: PPDS: Programmatic conversion of Planned Order to Production Order-ORDER_NOT_FOUND outside standard
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working on SAP APO / PPDS and trying to programmatically convert a PPDS planned order to a production order.

In the standard transaction (e.g. /SAPAPO/RPP7), the conversion works correctly. However, when I try to trigger the same logic from a custom ABAP program, I consistently receive the exception ORDER_NOT_FOUND.

I am currently calling the following function module
/SAPAPO/RRP_ORDER_SET_CNVIN

Observations
The same order exists and converts successfully when executed via the standard PPDS transaction.
The FM throws ORDER_NOT_FOUND when called from:
SE37
A custom Z-report
Some function modules mentioned online (e.g. order read helper FMs) do not exist in our APO release, suggesting a class-based PPDS runtime.
Understanding so far
It seems that standard PPDS transactions implicitly:

Initialize the planning context (planning version, session, liveCache)
Load the order into the PPDS buffer
Work with the internal PPDS ORDERID (GUID) rather than an external/display order number
Whereas in a custom program, this context is not initialized automatically, leading to ORDER_NOT_FOUND.

Questions
What is the SAP-recommended API (FM or class) to:
Retrieve the internal PPDS ORDERID
Convert a planned order to a production order programmatically?
What is the minimum required planning context initialization needed before calling the conversion logic?
Is there a released and supported approach for background/mass conversion outside the PPDS UI?
Any guidance, sample code, or SAP Notes would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

I have created a Popup with checkboxes (City selection).

When I unselect (untick) a checkbox and apply the selection,

only the tick mark should be removed.

Actual Behavior:
Unselected checkbox disappears from the popup list.

This issue happens after applying filters using script.

Please let me know:

- How to keep all checkbox values visible after unselecting

Screenshots attached for reference.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Looking to extend the Capacity Planning applications?
entry.content:
The Fiori apps like Capacity Scheduling Table, and Capacity Scheduling Board support UI-level extensibility, that will allow key users and functional experts to add custom fields and filters using key user extensibility features without writing custom code or requiring in-depth technical knowledge, I will introduce the possible changes by using application:

- Custom Fields

- Manage Characteristic as Custom Fields 

Before starting, lets introduce the Business Context available for each application:

1. On Capacity Scheduling Board: You can easily adjust the Order Details displayed and the Operation Info once adjusting elements of UI Technology using Business context: Master Data: Product General and Master Data: Product Plant to add fields

After adjustments you can follow the following Navigation Path to select your new Custom Fields

  • Capacity Scheduling Board app > Select an order operation > Order Details
  • Capacity Scheduling Board app > Select an order operation > Operation Info

2. On  Capacity Scheduling Table: Extensibilities are allowed to adapt New Fields to be selected on Filters criteria and change the Layout of the worklist displayed by adding new additional information customized using business context: Master Data: Product General, Master Data: Product Plant, Order Master Data, Manufacturing: Planned Order Header and Production Orders: Variant Configuration

After adjustments you can follow the following Navigation Path to select your new custom Fields:

  • Capacity Scheduling Table app > Worklist Search filters > Adapt Filters // Flexible Column Layout > Additional Information
  • Capacity Scheduling Table app > Orders Table > Settings // Flexible Column Layout > Additional Information

-----

As part of this blog, I would like to share a Usage case where a customer wanted to personalize the Capacity Planning table to add new custom object for Characteristics used in Variant configuration to segregate the orders/operation displayed and prioritize some fo then to take leveling action in the right time.

------

The CPS application brings integration for business where Advanced Variant Configuration is in place, by allowing the Navigation to the Variant Configuration Screen to view the product configuration for the production orders (indicated by an icon).

In terms of extensibility, the Capacity Scheduling Table app is allowed to add characteristics since release OP2022 and in Cloud Editions, where planners can utilize characteristics from VC specific information to segregate the orders/operation listed and use characteristics as part of the filter criteria.

To achieve this is needed you use ‚ÄòManage Characteristics as Custom Fields‚Äô App

IMPORTANT NOTE :

As per SAP Note: 3220904 characteristic-based Field Extensibility (CFE) solution is redesigned, new business context is introduced (PRODUCTION_ORDER_CFE), where data load logic for characteristic-based custom fields has been optimized, and characteristic master data synchronization has been improved. Old business context (PP_ORD_CONFIGURATION_CFE) is marked as obsolete and should not be considered. BTW, This business Context is applicable as well to enhance Manage Production Orders

Now, after selecting Production Orders ‚Äì Variant Configuration: PRODUCTION_ORDER_CFE (AFPO) will display the details of the Business Context, where you can click on Edit, which will be allow changes in Draft mode to enable the addition and select de desired characteristic, as example we will select ‚ÄòLOBM_APO_SL_MIN‚Äô, add a Custom Field description ‚ÄòMin Shelf Life‚Äô and click on Save

After saving, the characteristic will be added to the custom Fields list, wait for some time to allow the system to publish, if needed you could use Refresh status for updates, and shortly the Characteristic change to Status ‚Äúready to use‚Äù, and at the same time checking back on the initial screen, all the business context were displayed, you should now see the new Consolidate status marked as ready to used

Now, to make ACV characteristic custom fields visible and usable in Capacity Scheduling Table app it is also required to extend source by opening Fiori app ‚ÄòCustom Field‚Äô app, and into the ‚ÄúData Source Extensions‚Äù and click on the plus button ‚Äò+‚Äù to add an extension of data source

A new pop-up window named New Data Source Extension will appear to insert, here you will add Data Source: PP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTION_SRV; Description: ZPP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTION_SRV (or desired), and Extension ID: ZPP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTI, the correlative will be automatically predefined and gray out. Once all is maintained you can select Create

This automatically will open a new Field Section to maintain the available field. Here you can extend the Field Path of Worklist Scheduling Products under Available Field Section, and select the characteristic added in the previous step, then click Save it and Publish.

Be aware that I have created previously another custom characteristic to refer to the Max Shelf Life in my scenario.

Now after refreshing the screen, you will see on the Data Source Extension List the Extension published

Finally, you are now able can navigate to Capacity Scheduling app and adapt the filters or modify the layout by modifying the view setting as needed!!!

Hope you find the example relevant to facilitate some of the custom requests on the application!!

Regards,

Jennifer!!

entry.title: Re: TIMEOUT dump (11 min.) for RFC in low priority (runti...
entry.content: As mentioned by Sandra Rossi, it might not be clear how the session priority is determined. Please, check the SAP Note 2129291 - Session Priority and Work Process Quota in SAP Kernels >= 7.4x for details. Especially, it mentions that the priority inheritance concept takes place ('As background jobs run with low priority, any RFC sessions created as a result of background jobs making RFC calls will be created with low priority as well.'), should you need to run your RFC as low prio, start the main program as a background job.

entry.title: SAP AI Skills Gap Analysis: Are We Ready?
entry.content:
The SAP AI Skills Assessment results are out, and there's a fascinating exploration of the gaps and readiness across the globe. Since the initial publication, the dataset has grown from 68 to 141 responses spanning 10 countries. The study revalidates the 1.6-2.1 point gap between motivation and implementation across different geographies, identifying systemic challenges rather than measurement artifacts.

Key findings illustrate a persistent implementation challenge, an awareness trap, a governance thread, and a pronounced focus on S/4HANA. Though awareness and motivation are relatively high, actual implementation capabilities significantly lag behind, with only 6-17% of professionals globally ready to implement AI solutions.

The report suggests shifting the focus from awareness campaigns to hands-on enablement strategies to bridge this significant gap. To harness the high motivation levels, it recommends a detailed training and role-based learning path, along with practical implementation experiences. Visit the provided blog from Thomas Jenewein for an in-depth analysis and to view the complete results.

I am interested in hearing your thoughts on how organizations can effectively bridge the gap between high motivation for AI implementation and the actual skills required, ensuring that the enthusiasm for AI translates into real-world, impactful applications.  Please comment below.

entry.title: Technical AS-IS EA Canvas: Accelerating Assessments in Undocumented Environments
entry.content:
Introduction: The AS-IS Challenge in Clients Without Documentation

In Enterprise Architecture (EA) projects, the very first and most critical step is establishing an accurate AS-IS baseline. However, in many companies, formal documentation simply does not exist. Knowledge about applications, integrations, and infrastructure often lives only in the minds of employees.

In environments like this, trying to capture requirements directly into tools such as SAP LeanIX‚Äîor relying on long email threads‚Äîbecomes slow, inefficient, and error‚Äëprone.

To address this challenge and accelerate the Assessment phase, we developed and successfully applied the Technical AS-IS EA Canvas methodology.
You can access the methodology assets here:
üëâ link

The Solution: A Cognitive & Tactile Methodology Supported by AI

Our approach innovates by separating human interaction from metadata capture, using AI to produce high-fidelity insights from the workshop.

1. The Tactile and Visual Workshop (The Canvas)

The heart of the methodology is the Technical AS-IS EA Canvas, a large-format (A0/A1) printed board designed for collaborative mapping.

Key characteristics:

  • Structure: The Canvas visually separates the technology landscape into On-Premise, Cloud, and External, aligned with the TOGAF ADM phases.
  • Interaction: Participants use colored post-its (following ArchiMate patterns for Application, Technology, and Business) to map systems, while strings represent integration flows.
  • Capabilities: Tools like SAP Signavio Process Explorer are used during the session to anchor discussions and ensure the mapping reflects true business capabilities.

2. High-Fidelity Data Capture (Audio + AI)

The major differentiator of this methodology is how the technical metadata is captured:

  • Recording & Cognition: Instead of taking notes, the architect focuses on facilitating the session using a guided Cheat-Sheet. The entire session is recorded.
  • AI Synthesis: The audio is then processed by an AI engine that extracts the essential metadata:
    • protocols
    • integration frequency
    • triggers
    • pain points
    • non-functional requirements
    • security considerations
    • and other technical details often lost in traditional workshops

This ensures no insight is missed.

3. The Result: Structured Data Ready for SAP LeanIX

The combination of photo + audio + AI extraction produces a reliable and complete dataset.

  • Structured Output: AI produces clean, structured metadata from the discussion.
  • Direct Import: This dataset is formatted and imported into SAP LeanIX, feeding the EA repository with a high-confidence AS-IS.
  • Focus on To-Be: With the AS-IS complete, architects can move directly to Gap Analysis and To-Be Architecture, drastically accelerating the project lifecycle.

Conclusion

The Technical AS-IS EA Canvas methodology demonstrates how tactile, visual engagement combined with AI capabilities solves one of the biggest challenges in Enterprise Architecture: capturing knowledge in undocumented environments.

We were able to extract all relevant requirements, applications, and integration flows‚Äîbuilding a robust EA baseline in SAP LeanIX with confidence and speed.

This approach not only reduces risk but transforms the AS-IS assessment into an engaging, high-value experience for all participants.

What about you?

I would love to hear your experiences with AS-IS capture in undocumented environments.
How do you deal with missing documentation in EA projects?

Share your thoughts and let‚Äôs exchange best practices!

Transparency Note: This post was drafted with the assistance of an Artificial Intelligence model to ensure clarity and structure.

entry.title: Clean Core + SAP BTP ‚Äî The "Golden Ratio" for Utilities
entry.content:
• üî• Teaser: Clean Core + SAP BTP ‚Äî The "Golden Ratio" for Utilities üìà
  •  

Stop thinking of a "Clean Core" as a technical constraint. Start thinking of it as the launchpad for everything else.

In my work across real-world utility transformations, the truth is simple:

 

‚Ä¢ Clean Core = Stability.

‚Ä¢ SAP BTP = Innovation.

‚Ä¢ Together = Sustainability. If you are still modifying the core to meet new regulatory demands, you aren't building a foundation; you‚Äôre building a cage. You need an architecture that allows you to move fast without risking the "Engine Room."

 

The Big Question: How do you modernize without disrupting mission-critical billing, metering, and customer processes?

 

I‚Äôm dropping a deep dive soon on how SAP Build, Event Mesh, and AI Core create the decoupled, event-driven architecture modern utilities actually need to thrive.

 

Don't let your legacy code hold your future hostage. üí°

entry.title: BKP: AI-Assisted Input Assistance in the ‚ÄúManage Customer Returns‚ÄìVersion 2‚Äù App
entry.content:
Intro

Creating customer returns efficiently is a critical part of modern sales operations. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, we introduce AI-assisted input recommendations in the SAP Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Customer Returns ‚Äì Version 2‚Äù, designed to make returns order creation faster, more accurate, and more user-friendly. This article walks you through the business context, capabilities, and practical usage of this intelligent input assistance, helping you understand how it supports everyday work in customer returns management.

 

What You‚Äôll Learn

After reading this article, you will understand:

  • The business context behind AI-assisted input recommendations
  • How input assistance works during returns order creation
  • Prerequisites, and tips for successful usage

Business Context: Why Input Assistance Matters

The customer returns solution (Scope Item BKP) allows end users to create returns orders using the Manage Customer Returns ‚Äì Version 2 app. In real-life scenarios, users often face challenges such as:

  • New users may not yet be familiar with the app and need guidance to create returns orders effectively.
  • Users may be uncertain about the accuracy of certain values, such as the returns process variant.
  • Some users prefer to default specific values, such as logistical follow-up activities, based on the order or return reason.

To address these needs, we provide input assistance through an AI innovation called ‚ÄúAI-assisted input recommendations for returns order creation‚Äù .

 

AI-Assisted Input Recommendations: Overview and Benefits

The AI-assisted input recommendations are available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and work directly within the Manage Customer Returns ‚Äì Version 2 app.

Key Benefits

  • Increased Process Efficiency
    Data entry time is reduced as users can rely on AI-driven suggestions based on historical data.
  • Enhanced Data Accuracy
    The system recommends precise values for fields where users may be unsure, reducing errors.

Core Capabilities

  • Recommendations are shown in real time during returns order creation.
  • Suggestions are based on patterns learned from past returns orders with the same process variants.
  • The AI solution supports easy onboarding with Turnkey AI, provided conditions are met.
  • Input recommendations are automatically available.
  • Recommended values are ranked, and those with a prediction probability above 70% are highlighted.

Input and Output Fields Supported by AI

The AI-assisted input recommendations cover both document header and document item levels. The following shows the user input and related output fields:

How AI Input Assistance Works

Returns Order Header Creation

  1. Start by entering the document type and sales area.
  2. Once you enter the sold-to party, the system begins recommending values for the order reason.
  3. If a value has a prediction probability above 70%, it is highlighted (for example, Standard Return (009)).
  4. When opening the value list, the top recommended values are displayed.
  5. You must accept a highlighted value or choose a different one. If no confirmation is made, the system will prompt you during saving. 

Returns Order Item Creation

  1. Enter the product first. This triggers recommendations for additional fields, such as return reason and logistical follow-up activity.
  2. Recommended values appear in the value list. If none exceed the 70% probability threshold, no value is highlighted.
  3. When a value (for example, Receive into Plant) exceeds the threshold, it is highlighted.
  4. As you accept or enter more fields (such as return reason), the system continues recommending values for subsequent fields. For example, a refund code may be highlighted with a prediction probability of 100%.
  5. If you change a value such as the logistical follow-up activity, related fields may also be recommended. For instance, selecting Ship to Supplier (0005) may trigger a recommendation for the supplier number. 

     

  6. If you do not accept a highlighted recommendation, the system will display a confirmation pop-up later.
  7. Once all necessary fields are accepted, you can successfully save the returns order.

    Prerequisites and Important Tips

    To use AI-assisted input recommendations, the customer returns recommendation machine learning model must be trained, deployed, and activated.

    Training Options

    We provide two approaches:

    1. Auto Training (Turnkey AI)

    Turnkey AI is automatically activated if all the following conditions are met:

    • A Data Attribute Recommendation (DAR) connection is established
    • Minimum data volume requirements are fulfilled:
      • 3,000 eligible items for production systems
      • 1,000 eligible items for quality or test systems

    2. Manual Training

    For detailed steps on manual training or on how to cancel input recommendations, refer to the SAP online help portal:
    AI-Assisted Input Recommendations for Returns Order Creation | SAP Help Portal

    Summary

    AI-assisted input recommendations in Manage Customer Returns ‚Äì Version 2 app are designed to reduce effort, improve accuracy, and guide both new and experienced users through returns order creation. By learning from historical data and providing real-time suggestions, it helps ensure smoother processes and more confident decision-making in customer returns management.

    As customer return solutions continue to evolve its AI capabilities, features like this represent a practical step toward more intelligent, user-friendly enterprise applications.

entry.title: ‚ÄúSAP Fiori Overview and Implementation Guidelines for Functional Consultants‚Äù
entry.content:
What is SAP Fiori in S/4HANA?

SAP Fiori is a comprehensive suite of role-based applications designed to deliver a simple, intuitive, and consistent user experience across SAP systems.

It provides transactional, analytical, and fact sheet‚Äìbased applications that allow users to perform business activities efficiently on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.

 

 

 

Key Benefits of SAP Fiori

  • Intuitive and user-friendly interface
  • Task-based, simplified design to improve productivity
  • Faster processing with minimal training effort
  • Line-item‚Äìbased operational reporting for better visibility
  • Unified access to SAP GUI transactions and modern apps through a single Fiori Launchpad

 

 

 

Why Focus on User Experience (UX)?

SAP Fiori enhances:

  • User adoption through simplified screens
  • Operational efficiency by reducing clicks and processing time
  • Decision-making with real-time insights
  • Mobility, enabling users to work anytime, anywhere

 

 

 

A better user experience directly improves business performance and user satisfaction.

Types of SAP Fiori Applications

 

 

  1. Transactional Apps (Blue)
  • Used for creating, updating, and processing business data
  • Support daily business operations
  • Examples:
    • Create Purchase Order
    • Approve Leave Request
    • Post Goods Receipt
  1. Analytical Apps (Green)
  • Used for reporting and analytics
  • Provide KPIs, charts, and real-time insights
  • Help management monitor performance and trends
  1. Fact Sheet Apps (Orange)
  • Display detailed contextual information
  • Show related business data in one place
  • Examples:
    • Customer details
    • Material information
    • Vendor overview

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad

The SAP Fiori Launchpad acts as a central entry point that provides:

  • Access to Fiori apps and SAP GUI transactions
  • Role-based tiles
  • Personalized user experience
  • Integration of classic and modern SAP applications

 

 

 

Empowering Functional Consultants with SAP Fiori Knowledge

  1. Confirm Business Requirements

Identify all required:

  • Transactional apps
  • Analytical apps
  • Fact sheet apps

based on business needs.

  1. Refer to SAP Fiori Apps Library

Access the official SAP repository:

üîó https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com

Use this to:

  • Search for relevant apps
  • Check app type and functionality
  • View technical and implementation details

 

  1. Validate System Compatibility

Ensure the required Fiori apps are:

  • Supported for the current SAP version
  • Compatible with S/4HANA (On-Premise or Cloud)

 

  1. Ensure Application Activation

After validation:

  • Confirm required apps are activated by Basis/Fiori team
  • Follow configuration details mentioned in the Fiori Library
  • Refer to Implementation Information section for each app

 

 

  1. Verify Role Assignment

Ensure:

  • Appropriate business roles are assigned to the user
  • Roles match the configuration mentioned in the Fiori Library
  • Only then will the Fiori tiles be visible in the launchpad

(Role mapping is usually handled by the Security team)

 

 

  1. Confirm OData Service Authorization
  • Validate required OData services are activated
  • Ensure OData roles are assigned to the user
  • OData details can be found in the Implementation Information section of each app in the Fiori Library
  • Required for backend data access and app functionality

 

 

After completing all configuration and authorization steps, ensure that the respective Fiori applications are thoroughly tested and working correctly in the Development, Test, and Pre-QA systems before requesting business users to perform UAT.

entry.title: Re: LGM Knowledge Snippet: How do we determine carriers (as of now...)
entry.content:
Hello @beata_d,

I would like to comment on your question about the carrier propagation in the TU-based TM-EWM integration and Adv. SR. In both scenarios, the carrier defined in the freight order will be propagated to the EWM ODO.

TU-Based TM-EWM Integration

  • FU is assigned to a freight order and freight order is set to 'Load Plan Status (Stop) = Finalized'
  • => Freight order carrier is propagated to the EWM ODO (cf. 'Partner' tab)

Adv. SR (Transport-Driven Scenario)

  • FU is assigned to a freight order and freight order is set to 'Ready for Warehouse Processing'
  • => Freight order carrier is propagated to the EWM ODO

BR, Mathias

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: Intelligent Integration with AI Adapter
entry.content:
Overview

Enterprise integration is changing. The new AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite makes it easier to add generative AI to integrations, workflows, and automations. This is a shift from just moving data between systems to building integrations that understand context and act more intelligently.

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite(Cloud Integration), making it easier to use generative AI directly within integration flows on SAP BTP. It lets integration flow(iFlows) call AI or large language model services at runtime. It comes with two options:

  • AICore-GenAIHub: It connects to SAP AI Core through the GenAI Hub, giving access to multiple foundation models using a single, unified API.
  • Custom-OpenAI-Rest: It connects to external AI providers such as OpenAI through a simple REST based interface.

Architecture Overview

The AI Adapter is used as a receiver in an integration flow. SAP Integration Suite starts the call and sends the request to either SAP AI Core through the GenAI Hub or to OpenAI.

The AI service processes the request and sends the response back to SAP Integration Suite, where it is used in the next steps of the flow.

 

What can we do with it

With this AI adapter, you can run tasks like sentiment analysis, text classification, translation, or text summarisation directly inside an iFlow. It also allows real time data enrichment, for example analysing customer feedback before sending it to downstream systems. More advanced scenarios are possible too, such as AI driven routing decisions or smarter, automated error handling. When using the GenAI Hub, you can even switch between models without changing the integration logic.

What makes this important is how naturally AI fits into existing integration scenarios. Instead of building and maintaining separate microservices, teams can embed AI capabilities straight into the integration layer they already use. This reduces development effort, speeds up delivery, and keeps the overall architecture simpler.

Key benefits

  • Faster AI adoption
  • Intelligent and dynamic iFlows can be build
  • Flexibility through AI Core
  • Simplifies architecture with no middleware

Why it makes a difference

This matters because the AI Adapter changes how integrations are built and used. Rather than creating separate services or complex workarounds, teams can add large language model capabilities directly into their existing integrations. This cuts down development effort, speeds things up, and opens the door to smarter and more flexible automation.

AI Adapter availability and Documentation

The AI Adapter is available through SAP Business Accelerator Hub and can be consumed like other standard integration adapters. Its availability depends on the SAP Integration Suite service plan you are using, as not all plans support the same feature set. SAP provides further details in below SAP Notes which outline the supported capabilities across different service plans:

2903776 - SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Service Plans and Upgrade Paths - SAP for Me

3188446 - SAP Integration Suite Adapters on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub - SAP for Me

For more details on the adapter architecture, installation steps, configuration options, and documentation, you can refer to the official SAP documentation and resources at the links below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/ai-adapter?locale=en-US
https://api.sap.com/odata/1.0/catalog.svc/Files('6a7cc59b207e4eb384f3af502f8b503f')/$value

Conclusion

With the AI Adapter, SAP is clearly taking Integration Suite beyond traditional connectivity and orchestration. Integration is no longer just about moving data from point A to point B. It can now understand context, respond to changing situations, and deliver smarter, more meaningful outcomes.

For organisations looking to get more value from their data flows, whether that is customer engagement, document processing, real time insights, or flexible workflows, this opens up a whole new set of possibilities. If you are already using SAP BTP and Integration Suite, now is a great time to explore how AI powered integration can enhance your landscape in a very practical way.

entry.title: From Silos to Systems: The Rise of Reusable Web Components in Enterprises
entry.content:
Over three decades of leading and innovating in the IT industry, I‚Äôve closely witnessed the ripples of transformation from desktop apps to cloud-native apps, from the static web to dynamic frameworks, and now to design systems that are as smart as the code they bring to life. Yet, among all these shifts, one advancement shines for its capability to boost efficiency and scalability - the emergence of reusable web components in enterprise systems. 

Modern digital enterprises function in an era influenced by seamless user experiences, consistency, and speed. Whether you‚Äôre developing a global client platform or an internal dashboard, end-users demand streamlined, coherent interfaces and expect them to be rapid. That‚Äôs where reusable web components come as a strategic imperative. 

Tracing Reusability: From Code Libraries to Component Ecosystems 

In the early 2000s, software development teams had to start from the ground up for every new project. Developers usually copied and updated UI elements from one development project to another, often leading to poor maintainability, cumbersome codebases, and inconsistencies. 

The emergence of component-based architecture powered by frameworks like Vue, Angular, and React revolutionized everything. It helped developers consider modular units: navigation bars, modals, cards, and buttons, that can be reused and integrated like digital Lego blocks. This was more than just a technical advancement; it was a paradigm shift towards better scalability, collaboration, and efficiency. 

However, as organizations expanded and projects increased, even reusable components started to degrade. Different teams designed their own iterations of components, with slight variations in style or functionality. That‚Äôs when the design system comes into action! It's a central repository of reusable, controlled components that closes the gap between the design and development process. 

Reusable Components: A Key Driver of Enterprise Agility 

In an enterprise ecosystem, scaling isn‚Äôt an option; it‚Äôs essential. When handling multiple applications across different business units and locations, it might lead to expensive inconsistencies. 

Reusable web components help businesses in three significant ways: 

  • Consistency at Scale 
    A single, combined component library ensures every client-centric digital product follows the same design and interaction language. Whether it‚Äôs a sales CRM or a marketing site, protecting your brand image and UX quality is essential. 
  • Speed to Market 
    Developers can leverage pre-tested, deployment-ready components directly from the system. This helps with faster releases and drastically minimizes build times, providing a competitive edge in today‚Äôs digital economy. 
  • Operational Efficiency 
    Reuse eliminates redundancy and enables centralization of the maintenance process. Any updates or bug fixes to a single component roll out across all applications. This ensures long-lasting sustainability and better quality. 

I‚Äôve seen organizations redefine their development lifecycles by integrating component-driven design systems. Development projects that once took months are moving into the deployment phase in weeks. In particular, this is no longer about rapid delivery it‚Äôs about generating more reliable outcomes. 

Component-Driven Culture: Cultivating a Collaborative Mindset  

However, the efficiency of reusable web components doesn't totally depend on technological breakthroughs, it‚Äôs a cultural shift. 

For years, I‚Äôve witnessed that the true hurdles in scaling design systems do not depend on the code, but on cross-functional alignment. Product managers, developers, and designers must prioritize shared ownership instead of siloed activities. 

A reusable component goes beyond a UI block an agreement between design vision and functional implementation. When teams come together under a shared contract, design systems advance into dynamic ecosystems instead of fixed libraries. 

To achieve this, businesses must: 

  • Encourage a perspective of reuse before rebuild, which should be supported by internal evangelism and documentation. 
  • Foster a continuous feedback loop between the design and development team to ensure components stay current. 
  • Adhere to robust governance models to handle updates, design iterations, and adoption. 

The Next Phase: Smart, Context-Aware Components 

In the path forward, I‚Äôm confident the next leap of component evolution will be empowered by adaptability and intelligence. 

We‚Äôre already observing early indicators of AI-powered design systems, where components can automatically align their behavior or appearance based on the device productivity, accessibility preferences, and user context. 

Organizations investing early in designing modern, metadata-rich components can be ideally placed to use these innovative features and functionalities. Maintaining an equilibrium between human oversight and automation is essential, ensuring components remain relevant, compliant, and consistent while advancing continuously.

Key Challenges Along the Path 

Of course, no transformation is incomplete without hurdles along the way. Deploying reusable components at scale also comes with its own set of challenges: 

  • Style Drift ‚Äì Preventing development teams from customizing components in possible ways that undermine reliability. 
  • Implementation Hurdles - Facilitating legacy teams to shift to new, advanced systems and processes. 
  • Governance Complexity - Keeping components upgraded without interfering with existing deployments. 

Addressing these challenges requires a top-down commitment. Leaders need to promote the long-term impact of design systems and assign resources to ensure consistent improvement. 

Lessons from the Field 

Throughout my journey at Radixweb, I‚Äôve realized that the most resilient enterprise design systems highlight three key attributes: 

  • A Single Source of Truth - A thoroughly-documented, centrally governed component library often developed on technologies like Angular, React, or Web Components that help every digital team. 
  • All-Inclusive Collaboration - Designers, developers, and QA analysts are all equally responsible, ensuring each component adheres to technical performance and design precision benchmarks. 
  • Iterative Evolution - The system should never stop scaling and advancing. It adapts, refines, and grows alongside market, technology, and business needs. 

When these principles are in place, reusable web components not just simplify development but also become a key resource for digital innovation. 

Designed for Modularity, Developed for Tomorrow 

As organizations continue to adopt cloud-native architectures and AI-first operations, modular design will continue to guide us. Reusable components act as the bridge between secure digital environments and scalable, well-structured web application architectures that enable rapid innovation. 

Over the next few years, I expect enterprise design systems to become more self-governing, where performance insights and usage analytics automatically notify about the updates and modifications. The line between design and development is consistently fading for a good reason. Eventually, both domains will share the same objective - to deliver unified experiences across different platforms. 

Final Thoughts 

If there‚Äôs something I‚Äôve learned over two decades in IT, it's that adaptability drives advancement. Reusable web components underscore that adaptability, which allows enterprises to evolve faster with better control, to innovate with cohesion, and to expand without compromise. 

In the coming years, enterprises that follow this philosophy not just as a framework option, but as a strategic approach- will be leading the way to the next chapter of digital excellence. 

In today‚Äôs intertwined environment, it‚Äôs not about development anymore, but smarter, scalable development.

entry.title: Leveraging GenAI for automatic successor suggestions in SF SuccessFactors Succession Planning
entry.content:
Succession planning is a critical part of building a resilient and future-ready workforce. With rapidly changing business environments and evolving skill requirements, organizations need tools that help them identify and prepare the next generation of leaders.

In this blog i will cover end to end steps and showcase how Succession Planners can leverage Generative AI capabilities to  access a comprehensive reference list of potential successors. These successors are intelligently recommended by Gen AI based on a thorough analysis of their skills, competencies, and work experience.

Benefits ‚Äì

Compared with the Suggested Successors feature, this feature incorporates more role-related data sources in generating recommendations, providing more relevant results to help improve the effectiveness of succession planning.

Prerequisite:

- You're using the MDF or legacy position-based nomination method.

- You've migrated to Talent Intelligence Hub and enabled the Growth Portfolio.

- You've purchased the AI units license.

- You've enabled the Suggested Successors feature.

- You have the Administrator Permissions > Manage AI Capabilities > AI Services Administration permission.

RBP :

Administrator Permissions>AI Services Administration

User Permissions > AI Access> Assisted Successor Insights

User Permissions > Career Development Planning > Recommended Successors

Feature enablement -

Navigate to AI Services Administration >Talent using action search

 

 

When you've enabled the Suggested Successors feature, you can further enable the AI-Assisted Successor Recommendation feature and configure the criteria and weights used in the recommendations

You can configure the criteria and weights used in the recommendation based on client requirement.

The default configuration is 50% weight for "skills and competencies" and 50% for "work experience".

Steps for  calculation based on client requirement :

  1. Go to Admin Center  Nominations Setup.
  2. At the bottom of the page, choose whether to include the criteria "skills and competencies" and "work experience".
  3. Modify the weight of each criterion.

 

Note

A weight must be an integer between 0 and 100. All weights must add up to 100%.

  1. Save your changes.

If you choose to include both "skills and competencies" and "work experience", generative AI uses the following data to recommend successors:

  • Position-related job families, job roles, and job profiles in Job Profile Builder
  • Skills and competencies in the Growth Portfolio
  • Job information and external work experience in People Profile

We will be using employee - Emily Clark for the demo and will use GenAI feature for automatic suggested successor

Below are  Competencies of this employee under Growth Portfolio

Demo - 

As a Succession Planner Navigate to  Succession Org Chart > Position card >at the bottom click on Named Successors>and select the Add Successor button

 

Click on Generate 

You will get message as below while AI is working on generation of successor details

 

Note -

1.The generation process takes some time. Users can close the position card and do other tasks if they want. Once the results are ready, users get a notification in the global page header. They can select the notification entry to go directly to the recommendations on the position card.

2.If you are not getting the output you will get below error message and then you need to take action on below points

Below is the Output of AI generated data 

Note - You can still Regenerate again.

You can then add the successor by using Add button ; along with this you can see the i icon which will show you the reason due to which these employee were recommended as successor for Emily Clark

 

As per the screenshot you can see Carla Grant 's Competency "Accepting Direction" is matched Emily hence she was recommended ,in this way we can Leverage GenAI to check entire system and suggest us based on our Calculation which we defined in previous steps.

You can then further add the employee as successor and define the Readiness.

Leveraging generative AI capabilities, succession planners can gain insights into the successors that are nominated for a position or an incumbent, on the position card in the Succession Org Chart or the Position Tile view.

Below is the result of insights generated by AI 

 

Final output : Emily Clark got Carla Grant as her successor . 

Once the employee is nominated, they are removed from the list. 

Conclusion :

SAP SuccessFactors Succession Planning, enhanced with Generative AI, marks a decisive shift toward intelligent, data-driven talent decisions. By automatically identifying potential successors based on data from job families, roles, and profiles in Job Profile Builder; Job Information; skills and competencies captured in the Growth Portfolio; and internal and external work experience from the People Profile‚Äîensuring recommendations are aligned with both current roles and future skill requirements.

Hope this Blog will help consultants in leveraging the AI features provided by SAP.

entry.title: How To Trigger Inbound Delivery With API in SAP Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Public Cloud system API functions correspond to the BAPIs in the on-premise system and are also used as service methods.

When using APIs, an integration process can be designed between the SAP system and a third-party system. If the data is triggered by SAP, the APIs will run via Outbound Services; if data is sent from a third-party system to SAP, Inbound Services will be used.

In order to trigger APIs or use them in integration processes, Communication System, Communication Arrangement, and Communication User are created in the Public Cloud system.

Communication System  

The Communication System can be described as a service name. By accessing the Communication System application, the System ID and System Name are entered, the relevant link is pasted into the Host Name field, and the process is completed by clicking the Save button.

 

Communication Arrangements

A Communication Arrangement is the application name that specifies which APIs will be used in the data-triggering process assigned to the previously created Communication System.

The created Communication System is assigned to a specific communication scenario.

 

Maintain Communication User

A Communication User is created within the existing Communication System and Communication Arrangement and serves as a kind of filter that indicates which user is triggering the service.

After the User Name is created, a password is required. To obtain the password, the Propose Password button is clicked and a proposed password is generated. This password is then used to trigger the relevant API when selecting Try Out on www.api.sap.com

SAP Business Accelator Hub

Afterwards, the Communication User is saved by clicking the Save button, and the API links are accessed. The desired API is then found, and the triggering screen can be reached by clicking the Try Out button.

After that, a specific triggering screen must be prepared in order to use the relevant method. This triggering screen can be considered similar to SE37; the link used when creating the Communication System and the port information are entered, and a display name is assigned for the screen. Additionally, the user name and password obtained while creating the Communication User are entered into the relevant fields.

 

Since the triggering process will be executed based on this API, an inbound delivery document must be created in the system.
The delivery 180000009 has been created in the system. After the delivery is created, the relevant method must be determined. For the inbound delivery, a token number is obtained by entering the delivery number into the parameter field of the GET method located under the Header tab. This token number can be considered as a kind of access key that enables data triggering in the system.

NOTE: When entering the delivery number, it must be written as '180000009'. The quotation marks ' ' must not be omitted.
NOTE: Under the Headers parameter, in order to retrieve a token from the system, ‚Äúx-csrf-token‚Äù must be entered and ‚Äúfetch‚Äù must be written as its value.

After the system is run, it returns a response and provides the token number.

 

After the relevant token number is obtained, when the delivery with status A is triggered using the PostGoodsReceipt method, it changes to status C, as if approval has been completed. While attempting to post the goods receipt using the PostGoodsReceipt method, the token obtained must be entered under the Headers section. In addition, the if-match header is added and an asterisk (*) is entered as its value. The purpose of this symbol is to prevent the system from encountering errors while scanning deliveries. After that, the system is run.

After the system is run, a response is received, and the response code is 200. A 200 response indicates that the goods receipt has been successfully posted in the system.

After the system returns the 200 success message, the delivery status is checked.
If errors such as 401, 403, etc. are received from the system, the delivery should be reviewed and verified. Not every error that occurs after triggering the APIs is explicitly indicated by the system. The delivery may be open and pending, the posting period may be closed, the put-away quantity may be entered incorrectly, and many other scenarios should be considered.

As a result, the successful response received from SAP (HTTP 200) confirms that the API integration was executed correctly and the goods receipt was posted without any technical issues. This demonstrates that the Communication System, Communication Arrangement, and Communication User were configured properly, and that the inbound service flow functions as expected. Any non-technical errors that may occur after this step should therefore be evaluated directly on the business document and system configuration side rather than the API integration itself.

Regards,

entry.title: How to Configure an API Proxy: From Provider Setup to Testing
entry.content:
Introduction :  Application Programming Interface which allows to communicate with SAP systems for different software applications. Simply they let you read ,update , create records in SAP.  Also helps you to Integrate SAP with Non SAP systems via cloud services or webapps.

We have 3 types of API's 

1.SOAP

2.REST

3.ODATA

In the below steps you'll know how to create API's and assign the target endpoints , resources respectively

Step 1: Create API Proxy

  • Go to Configure and create a new API Proxy.
  • Select the respective API Provider that has already been created.
    Note: If the provider does not exist, create a new API Provider using the credentials provided.

 

Step 2: Configure Provider Details

  • Select the provider and enter the Target URL.
  • Fill in all required details using the proper naming conventions (API name, version, description, etc.).

 

Step 3: Select Service Type

  • Choose the appropriate service type (e.g., REST, SOAP, ODATA).
  •  Click on create  , the API proxy will be created.

 

Step 4: Configure Target Endpoint (Routing Conditions) If routing conditions are required:

    • Navigate to the Target Endpoint.
    • Add the required routing rules/conditions.

Step 5: Configure Proxy Endpoint

  • Go to the Proxy Endpoint.
  • Add the conditions.
  • Map the condition to the Target Endpoint created in Step 4.

 

Step 6: Policies and Deployment

  • Save the configuration.
  • Apply the required policies (security, logging, transformation, etc.).
  • Deploy the API Proxy to the required environment.

Step 7: Add Resources (If Required)

  • If resources are not created automatically:
    • Download the YAML file from API Hub.
    • Import it into API Designer.

Note:

  • For most REST ,ODATA, SOAP APIs, resources are created automatically.
  • If not, resources can be added manually and tested.

 

Step 8: Authorization and Parameters (GET / POST)

For GET and POST operations, ensure the following parameters are added after parameters section:

for GET you need to add after parameters section where for POST need to add after tag which means we need to add the parameters as well for POST operation

- $ref: '#/components/parameters/authorization'
- $ref: '#/components/parameters/legalEntityId'

Step 9: Testing

  • Test the API using Postman.
  • Pass the routing name value in the legalEntityId parameter in headers of postman.

Summary : The vital steps to setup basic API its types , creation of an API  and assigning the target endpoints setting up the routing conditions accordingly and assign the resources manually using YAML file and deploying it.

entry.title: TMS on SAP Integration Suite for API proxy transports in SAP API Management
entry.content:
Purpose

Moving API proxies between different tenants can be a critical step in your development lifecycle. This article provides a clear, step-by-step guide on how to successfully set up the Transport Management System (TMS) to handle API proxy transports, building on the assumption that you already have TMS configured for your Integrations. 

Prerequisites
Before beginning the setup, ensure the following entitlement is available in both your source (e.g., Development) and destination (e.g., Production) subaccounts:

  • API Management, API portal

Process
Step:1: Create a service instance for the API Management, API portal entitlement using the apiportal-apiaccess plan. This needs to be done in both your source and destination subaccounts

 

Step:2: For the instances created in Step 1, generate a service key in both the source and destination subaccounts. Crucially, ensure you copy and securely store both service keys, as they contain the credentials and URLs required for the following steps.

Step:3: In the Connectivity section of the Cockpit for your source subaccount, create a new Destination (From Scratch). This destination will allow your source environment to connect and push transports to the destination environment. The details that is used in configuring this destination is from the service key details of destination environment (Production in my case)

 

ParametersValues
NameAPIManagement
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
TypeHTTP
Client IDFrom Destination JSON Key File
Client SecretFrom Destination JSON Key File
Token Service URLFrom Destination JSON key file
URL{{ URL from Destination JSON key File}}/api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport
Token Service URL TypeDedicated

Step:4: Once the destination configuration is complete, you should be able to initiate the transport of API proxies (and API Providers) from your source tenant. A new Transport Request (TR) will be generated and visible in your Cloud Transport Management System.

You should be finding this TR in your Transport Request of Transport Management System.

Problems faced

Configuration Issues
If any of the below errors are encountered when initiating the transport, check the destination configuration in source subaccount / tenant (Step:3). All the above errors are due to incorrect destination configuration. Check if you have the correct destination name, correct URL in destination configured (destination service key URL with path /api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport), correct credentials (destination service key credential)



Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Destination configuration error in APIManagement . Bad credentials sap apim
Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Validation failed as destination APIManagement not configured with correct URL

 

Dependency Issues
If the below error is encountered, then the integration artifact that this API represents / linked is not actually present in destination tenant or subaccount. First transport the corresponding integration artifacts first then transport the API artifact.

The artifact you're attempting to transport could not be found or has encountered an error. Please verify that the artifact exists and try again. If the problem continues, contact SAP Support for assistance

Configuration Issues
Following error might occur during transport immediately after adding Transport description and clicking Yes. This might be due the special characters in the description provided. Please avoid giving special characters in transport description.

Similar to adding special characters in integration artifact transport and you encounter the following error.

This is due to the presence of special characters in Transport description as mentioned in this KBA. The characters specified in this KBA are too not accepted in API transports. Better to avoid any special characters in transport description.

Result

If you have all the pre-requisite complete along with the above steps, we should readily be able to do the API Proxy transports, API Provider transports from source subaccounts to destination subaccounts. Once you click transport from the source, it should create a transport ID and a transport request that can be seen in Cloud TMS with the API details.

entry.title: Re: Maintaining average inspection duration or GRPT based...
entry.content:
Greetings,

are you perhaps using early inspection lot creation or is the inspection lot create inspection created with goods receipt?

Anyway I think three options are possible:

  1. As mentioned before you could add an operation to the task list used in the production version that would reflect the average inspection time (you need to be careful regarding the affect on calculation)
  2. Maintain an additional inspection type of origin 04 and link it to production version with development. You would need help from developers to create the inspection lot of correct inspection type.
  3. If you are using EWM you could perhaps find a solution at a storage location level or try using inspection rules (quality inspection group for example)

I think the first one is the most standard and the most basic one if you are looking for a way to incorporate the average inspection time in the material lead time.

Best regards, M.

entry.title: Re: Backdate posting in WM SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello @Charisma_fitra 

Thank you for your question

There is a processual issue with that approach. Let me explain.

The final material document posting in public cloud with embedded EWM managed storage location is created when your warehouse step is executed. For example, GR or GI posting from your warehouse process. During that integration, the system updates the ERP/MM document with the current date as the posting date when EWM posts to ERP. You can read about that behaviour in KBA 2574109

Here is my suggestion:

  1. If you need a backdate posting, you must enter the posting date at your warehouse good movement posting step, which is the step that actually creates the material document and not only at the initial IM entry.
  2. If your warehouse step already posted today‚Äôs date, then reverse your goods movement and repost it with the correct posting date. Note that the system only allows you to do this if the posting period is still open and your process allows for reversals.
  3. If you are trying to backdate through classic IM while your storage location is EWM managed, that posting date will not survive if the actual posting is later executed by the EWM integration. This is because the Warehouse posting derives the MM posting date. See KBA 2574109 for more details.

Question:

What exactly do you mean by ‚ÄúWM processed‚Äù? is that a warehouse step (for example GR, PGI, etc)?

Best regards

Chris
